arguments.name: Dark Mode Feature Implementation
arguments.description: Project to track implementation of dark mode support across our application

arguments.name: Dark Mode Feature Implementation
arguments.description: Project to track implementation of dark mode support across our application

arguments.name: Implement Dark Mode UI Support
arguments.problem_statement: Users need the ability to switch between light and dark themes for better visual comfort, reduced eye strain in low-light environments, and improved battery life on OLED displays. The current application only supports a light theme.
arguments.success_criteria:
1) Users can toggle between light and dark modes via settings or system preference detection
2) All UI components properly render in both themes with appropriate color contrasts
3) Dark mode respects OS-level theme preferences automatically
4) Theme persistence across sessions and user accounts
5) No visual regressions or broken layouts in either theme
arguments.description: Implement comprehensive dark mode support including CSS variables, component theming, system preference detection, and user-controlled toggles. Ensure accessibility compliance with WCAG contrast requirements.

arguments.description: Project for implementing user notifications feature
arguments.name: Notifications Implementation

arguments.problem_statement: Build a comprehensive user notification system that allows users to receive timely updates about workunit changes, task assignments, comments, and other relevant events. The system should support multiple notification channels (email, in-app, push), user preferences for subscription management, and scalable delivery mechanisms.
arguments.success_criteria: Users can configure their notification preferences per channel; notifications are delivered reliably within 5 seconds of triggering events; the system handles at least 1000 concurrent users without degradation; all notification types have been tested and verified; documentation is complete.

arguments.title: Design Notification System Architecture
Quarterly Audit Review - Authentication Workunits
arguments.content: This workunit was reviewed during the quarterly audit. Current status confirmed as active.

arguments.title: Switched to WebSockets for real-time notifications
arguments.content:
We decided to use WebSockets instead of polling for our real-time notification feature. This architectural decision was made after considering the tradeoffs:

**Polling approach (rejected):**
- Simpler to implement initially
- No persistent connections needed
- Easier to scale horizontally with stateless servers
- Higher latency for notifications (depends on poll interval)
- Wastes bandwidth and server resources with frequent empty requests
- Battery drain on mobile devices due to constant polling

**WebSocket approach (chosen):**
- True real-time delivery with minimal latency
- More efficient use of network resources (single persistent connection)
- Better battery life for mobile users
- Bidirectional communication capability for future features
- Requires managing connection state and reconnection logic
- May need additional infrastructure for WebSocket load balancing
- Slightly more complex to implement initially

The decision favors user experience and efficiency, accepting the added complexity of maintaining persistent connections. We'll implement proper reconnection handling and fallback mechanisms where appropriate.
